required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Novel Determinants and Measures of Smokeless Tobacco Use: Study 2
clinical_study.official_title: Novel Determinants and Measures of Smokeless Tobacco Use: Study 2 Effects of Switching Levels of Nicotine and TSNA in Products on Smokeless Tobacco Use

lead_sponsor.agency: University of Minnesota - Clinical and Translational Science Institute

clinical_study.source: University of Minnesota - Clinical and Translational Science Institute

brief_summary.textblock: The research project will determine the level of nicotine in ST products that will lead to the greatest reduction in toxicant exposure

detailed_description.textblock: This is a randomized, multi-site trial determining the effects of switching smokeless tobacco (ST) users to lower toxicant ST products which vary in nicotine levels on biomarkers of exposure and patterns of use. ST users will undergo a two week baseline assessment period and then randomly assigned to one of three oral tobacco products (lower NNK plus NNN product with three different levels of nicotine) for a period of 8-weeks. Follow-up will occur at 9 and 20 weeks.

primary_outcome.measure: 1. To determine if switching to ST products with reduced toxicant levels will result in reduction of biomarkers of exposure and toxicity. 2. To determine the nicotine levels of ST that would lead to the greatest reduction in tobacco toxicant exposure.

secondary_outcome.measure: To determine the extent to which varying low nicotine ST products leads to compensatory tobacco use.

arm_group.description: Conventional smokeless tobacco product with 1) NNN plus NNK of <2 μg/gram and nicotine levels of >5 mg/g wet weight
Conventional smokeless tobacco product with ) NNN plus NNK of <2 μg/gram and nicotine levels of 3-5 mg/g wet weight.
Conventional smokeless tobacco product with NNN plus NNK of <2 μg/gram and nicotine levels of <3 mg/g wet weight

intervention.description: Comparison of different dosages of nicotine effect on tobacco use patterns, subjective response and biomarker levels.
Comparison of different dosages of nicotine effect on tobacco use patterns, subjective response and biomarker levels.
Comparison of different dosages of nicotine effect on tobacco use patterns, subjective response and biomarker levels.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
1. Using a consistent and daily amount of ST with specific nicotine and tobacco-specific nitrosamine (TSNA) levels for the past year;
2. In good physical health (no unstable medical condition);
3. Stable, good mental health (e.g., no recent unstable or untreated psychiatric diagnosis, including substance abuse, as determined by the DSM-IV criteria).
Exclusion Criteria:
1. Subjects must not be currently using other tobacco or nicotine products.
2. Female subjects cannot be pregnant or nursing.

overall_official.affiliation: University of Minnesota - Clinical and Translational Science Institute
